Metadata.Title: JSESSIONIDs Are Stored in the URL When Cookies Are Disabled

Content.Data:
What to Check For

Verify that JSESSIONIDs are stored inside the URL when cookies are disabled by the browser.

Why

JSESSIONIDs are the identifiers that match a client to a session. The use of truly random JSESSIONID makes it difficult for an attacker to hijack the session and impersonate a user.

How to Check

Session management encompasses the techniques employed by web applications to transparently authorize a user for every HTTP request without requiring the user to repeatedly login. J2EE session management uses a session-specific session identifier, JSESSIONID, which is created at the start of each session. If your application needs to keep track of user sessions, use the following steps to ensure that your application tracks sessions securely:

  1. Ensure your application verifies the use of cookies. Check if your application verifies whether users' browsers have cookies enabled. If cookies are enabled, verify that sessions are handled via the use of cookies.

  2. Ensure your application can use sessions if cookies are disabled. If cookies are disabled, verify if your application uses HttpServletResponse.encodeURL to store the JSESSIONIDs in the URL. Example:

    String url = request.getRequestURL().toString();
           url = response.encodeURL(url);
                 response.sendRedirect(url);

  3. Ensure that JSESSIONIDs are stripped out from the URL upon visiting external links. Verify that your application sanitizes its URL when visiting external sites. Ensure that all JSESSIONIDs are removed when exiting your application.

Problem Example

The following code shows the login interaction between the application and the user. Once the user requests the initial page, the application forwards them to the login screen. Upon verifying the credentials, the application loads the main application interface. Unfortunately, the application does not check whether the client supports cookies; therefore causing a broken access control as the valid user may not be able to access the application.

<%-- The application fails to check whether the client supports cookies --%>
